pretty fast to cover as much ground as we're going to cover all right so we have a lot to cover so let's get started
but before we get into the tools I want to make sure that we're all on the same page about what artificial intelligence
is so we need to answer the question what is modern data driven Ai and to
answer this question we need to start with AI itself so artificial intelligence is a subfield of computer science that attempts to create machines
that act rationally in response to their environment and AI is any machine that perceives its environment and chooses
actions that maximize the expected likelihood of achieving a goal of some kind essentially it's just a machine that takes data as input and produces
the best possible output given what it currently knows some examples of AI include computers
that can play chess robots that can vacuum your floor non-player characters and video games and the navigation
software on your smartphone essentially any computer algorithm that replicates some aspect of human intelligence or
natural intelligence is essentially a form of artificial intelligence now all modern data driven AI are most
modern data driven AI is all based on machine learning so what is this machine learning stuff well Machine learning is
a subfield of artificial intelligence that's Based on data and statistics it involves machines learning how to solve
problems without being explicitly programmed to do so so we're not typing if this then that it's learning how to
do so by detecting statistical patterns in data essentially with machine learning we use
existing data and a training algorithm to learn a model of the data then we can
feed new data into that model that it's never seen before and the model will make a prediction about this new data
now a machine learning model is essentially just a function it's simply a mapping from an input to an output of
some kind and in the most basic case with machine learning we're essentially using a model to take data as input and
then that model is producing some kind of prediction or decision as output and this is a very important point to
make because every example that we're going to see here today is essentially just some kind of function we're mapping
some kind of input to some kind of output and you'll see this pattern over and over and over again in both machine
learning and artificial intelligence so in terms of this mapping between inputs and outputs there are two main types of
input output mappings that are sets of tasks of these input output mappings that we can perform with machine
learning we can either perform data analysis or we can perform data synthesis so analysis is where we take
complex High dimensional data as input and then reduce it to lower dimensional more abstract data as output for example
converting text audio or video into a single number or label of some kind
synthesis on the other hand is where we take lower dimensional more abstract data as input and then produce higher
dimensional more complex data as its output for example converting simple text into more complex audio or video
speaking that text out loud throughout this presentation we're going to group all of our models first by the
type of data that they involve and then second as either an analysis task in blue or synthesis task in green and this
is going to help you to build a mental model of the entire landscape of artificial intelligence and the various tasks that we can perform with modern
data-driven AI and finally there are three main types of machine learning models we have pre-trained models augmented models and
custom models and now pre-trained models are essentially off-the-shelf Solutions they've been previously trained by a
third party like Microsoft Google or Amazon to perform a general task and then they're ready to use with little to
no additional effort from you as a developer for example Microsoft has a pre-trained vision service that allows
you to detect people's faces in an image simply just make a rest API call and you get an answer back
now on the far other end of the spectrum we have these custom do-it-yourself models where you have to provide the
training data the compute power and the expertise in order to create a model that will perform a specific task for
you or your business for example if you wanted to predict customer Revenue based on your customers uh Financial history
um you would need to use your own company's data you need to use your own compute power and your own expertise to create this model from scratch
augmented models are somewhere in between so the models are pre-trained by a third party like Microsoft Amazon or
Google and then you transfer the learning from your more specific task to that from the more General task to your
more specific task for example if you wanted to detect your company's logo in images you could use a pre-trained
vision model and then apply transfer learning by giving it a few examples of your company's logo and then it's going
to essentially detect just your company's logo in the images going forward now I've ordered these three types of
models by their level of difficulty complexity and cost so I always recommend that you start with the easiest pre-trained models first and
only work your way to the more complex custom models if and when necessary
all right so now let's get into the actual tasks that we can use these tools for so first we're going to look at
learn how to use AI tools to work with tables of data so tables are how we organize structured
data about our world they can contain data about scientific observations business transactions physical entities
and more as a result they're the most common form of structured data that we encounter in information technology
tabular data or simply data stored in rows and Columns of a table now on the rows we typically have the individual
observations transactions or entities and on the columns we typically have the
individual variables Properties or attributes and there are two main types of data that we can store in these tabular data
types both categorical and numerical data so categorical data represent named
qualities of things for example true or false various colors or t-shirt sizes whereas numerical data represent
quantities of things for example integers decimals floating Point numbers and so on and there's a variety of data
analysis tools that we have available to us for working with tabular data for example classification regression
recommendation and more so let's just take a look at classification which I think is the easiest of these to
understand so classification allows us to assign a row of data to two or more categories
essentially it answers what kind of data is in this Row in the table or how would we classify this row of data
so for example you can use a customer's data to approve or reject a credit card application we provide the model with
the customer's Financial data's input and then the model produces a label indicating the likelihood of repaying
the credit card on time and a confidence score in that prediction as its output classification is useful for tasks like
automating the approval or rejection of bank loans detecting potential fraud during credit card transactions and
predicting customers who are about to leave us for their competitor or for competitors which we call customer churn
now Beyond classification we have a variety of other data analysis tools available for tabular data for example
regression where we use existing rows of data to predict numeric values for those new rows
recommendation where we suggest data that are similar in some way to other data like products services or movies
that we're recommending clustering where we group rows of data together based on similarities to one
another Association where we determine the strength of the relationship between connected rows of data
anomaly detection where we determine which data are a typical or abnormal compared to the rest of the data
now in addition to the data analysis tools that we've just seen there's also a variety of data synthesis tools for
tabular data for example data imputation data generation and data transformation so we're going to take a look at
imputation now imputation allows us to predict which value of a missing predict values
of missing categorical or numerical data essentially it answers the question what data should go in this missing spot or
you know how would I fill in this data based on all the other data around it essentially it's doing this in a
statistically sensible way so for example imagine we've got a table of weather data and we have a bunch of
missing sensor data readings from various days now if we we would provide the model with this input table of data
containing the missing values and then the model is going to produce a complete table with those missing values filled
in with sensible alternative values or replacement values now imputation is useful for tasks such as creating data
visualizations that require complete data performing aggregate data analysis that requires summing values together
where you need all of the values and creating machine learning data sets that require complete data in order to train
the model now beyond that imputation we've also got a few other types of data synthesis
tools for example data generation which allows us to synthesize entire tables of data from scratch while preserving the
statistical characteristics of a source tab table of data and data transformation which allows us
to convert data from one format into a second format simply by giving it a few examples of what we what the
transformation should look like and so as we can see there's a variety of tools now available to software
Developers for working with tabular data and these include both tools for data analysis as well as data synthesis
so next we're going to learn how to use AI tools for working with text Now text is how we communicate
information to one another via written language it's the primary type of data that we encounter in books articles and
emails and as a result it's one of the most valuable forms of unstructured data that exists in information technology
textual data are data that are represented as a body of text like this example passage from Shakespeare we
typically store textual data as an array of characters of an arbitrary length each letter number and symbol are
represented as a binary value within this array and there are a variety of AI tools that
we can use to perform analysis on text in this format which we also call natural language processing or NLP these
text analysis tools include text classification sentiment analysis entity recognition and more so we'll take a
look at the simplest of these which is text classification text classification allows us to assign
a body of text to two or more categories in essence it answers the question what kind of text is this or how should we
assign this text to a category for example we could classify inbound emails
by the department that typically handles them we provide the model with the text contained in an email's input and then
the model produces a prediction of which department the email should be routed to as its output
text classification is useful for tasks such as organizing legal documents based on the type of case that they involve
categorizing support tickets by the type of issue and classifying spam email is
either spam or not spam but beyond text classification we also have a variety of other text analysis
tools for example sentiment analysis which allows us to determine if a body of text has either positive or negative
emotional sentiment entity recognition which allows us to identify specific persons places or
things in a body of text Beyond Simple word matching tone analysis which is like sentiment
analysis but for different types of emotion and tone in emails or in text language detection which allows us to
determine the language of a written body of text and syntax analysis which organizes
words into a hierarchical tree representing each word they're part of speech and their syntactical relationship
now in addition to the text analysis tools there's also a variety of text synthesis tools these include tools like
text completion text generation language translation and more so we'll take a look at text completion
text completion allows us to predict missing words or upcoming words in essence it answers the question what
word is missing here or what word is most likely to come next for example we can use text completion
to predict what words a user is likely to type next into their smartphone we provide the model with the text of an
incomplete sentences input and then the model produces the most likely text and a confidence score as output
text completion is useful for tasks such as autocompleting sentences while you're typing correcting transcription errors
while transcribing from videos or verifying sentence syntax by checking the probability of occurrence of each
word in a sentence to see whether that word makes sense there or not now Beyond text completion there's also
a variety of other text synthesis tools including text generation which allows us to generate an entire body of text
based on a simple text prompt language translation which allows us to
convert from one language to another language text summarization which reduces a very
large body of text down into a little tdlr summary of or synopsis of the text
language transliteration which can convert words from one alphabet into words that are pronounceable in a second
alphabet and program synthesis which converts visual descriptions in pseudocode into
actual source code that can be run by a computer um Has anyone used like either codex or like uh get uh githubs okay and did

available to Developers for working with text and these include both tools for text analysis as well as text synthesis

and services all right so third we're going to learn how to use AI tools to work with audio
so audio is how we hear the world and speak to one another and as a result audio is essential to our understanding
of the world around us audio data are typically stored as a one-dimensional array of numeric values each value
represents a sample of the amplitude of a sound wave recorded at a specific time and then these samples are ordered
across time to create a temporal representation of the recorded sounds for Monroe sound recordings we just have
a single audio Channel and thus a single array of values for stereo data we have two channels that is the Left Channel
and a right channel as a result stereo audio data typically contain two channels one for each audio Channel then
synchronized across time and there are a variety of va tools that we can use for audio analysis and these
include sound classification speaker recognition speech recognition and more so let's take a look at sound
classification now sound classification allows us to assign a sound to two or more labeled
categories essentially it answers the question what kind of sound is this for example we can use sound classification
to determine which type of animal produce a specific vocalization or noise we provide the model with the following
audio samples input I'm going to play a sound hopefully it's not too loud wow and then just like our ears can
predict what kind of thing that is the model is going to produce an answer as to what it thinks that sound came from
and a confidence score for that prediction as its output sound classification is useful for
things like detecting gunshots and audio surveillance systems predicting mechanical failure from acoustical anomalies and identifying species of
wildlife for wildlife conservation but beyond sound classification we have
a variety of other audio analysis tools for example speaker recognition which allows us to determine who is speaking
in a sound recording speech recognition which allows us to convert spoken dialogue into written
text sound detection which identifies the beginning and end of each sound event in
a noisy environment sound localization which can locate the source of a sound in either a two or
three dimensional space and song recognition which identifies a
song based on a short audio snippet I'm sure some of you have used like Shazam or something to figure out what song's
playing on the radio but now in addition to these audio analysis tools there's also a variety of
audio synthesis tools these include speech synthesis voice synthesis speech translation and more so let's look at
the most basic which is speech synthesis also known as text to speech so speech
synthesis allows a computer to communicate to us using spoken words essentially it allows a computer to
speak out loud using an artificial human voice for example we can use speech synthesis
to read text out loud to us we provide the model with the following text as input and then the model is going to
produce the following audio as output hi my name is Matthew renzi now obviously
it's not the sound of my voice saying that and you can tell it's not entirely human but it's getting better and better
each year to the point where it's going to be very soon we won't be able to distinguish whether we're talking to a human on the other end of the phone or a
machine in fact if those of you that have seen Google's demo where they essentially had a voice assistant placing a haircut appointment the person

we also have a speed synthesis being useful for things like detecting responses to requests for hands-free
applications narrating text contained in documents and for creating more natural user interfaces
but beyond speech synthesis there's now also a variety of other audio synthesis tools for example
voice synthesis which takes a recording of a person's voice like this hi my name is Matthew rinzi in addition to text
transcript edits like that down there and it's going to produce new audio output combining my voice with the edits

so fourth we're going to learn how to use AI tools for working with images and for me personally I think this is where
things start to get really interesting so our world is highly visual we drive most of our information about the world
through our eyes the spaces we navigate the faces we interact with and the documents we read are all processed
visually as a result images are one of the most valuable types of unstructured data that exist for modern AI
an image captures a digital picture of the world however if we zoom in we can see that a digital image is actually
composed of a bunch of tiny squares we call this a raster of pixels a two-dimensional grid of picture elements
we represent this raster of pixels as either a two-dimensional array or Matrix of numeric values and each numeric value
corresponds to the intensity of the light captured at a specific X and Y position of the image sensor for color
images we typically have separate rasters of pixels for each color Channel as a result color images will be
composed of three grids corresponding to red green and blue color channels respectively
now similar to audio we can have both monocular images that is a flat two-dimensional image or we can have a
stereo image which allows us to see depth by Optical Parallax and depth also helps us to determine the position of
objects relative to the observer in space and there are a variety of AI tools that
we can use now for image analysis and these include image classification object detection face recognition and
more so let's take a look at the simplest which is image classification so image classification allows us to
assign an image to two or more labeled categories essentially it answers the question what kind what's contained
within this image or what is this thing I'm seeing here for example we can use image classification to tag the content
of an image we provide the model with an image as its input and then the model is going to produce a category label and a
confidence score as its output image classification is useful for tasks like Auto tagging images on social media
posts detecting visual defects or product defects via visual inspection or diagnosing medical issues like detecting
certain types of skin cancer but Beyond image classification we have a variety of other image analysis Tools
in fact there are too many to cover all in one short presentation but I'll briefly cover as many as I can so we
have things like object detection which allows us to identify the location of various objects within an image we have
face recognition which allows us to determine who is contained in an image we have reverse image search which
allows us to find images that are visually similar to a source image we have image captioning which generates a
text description of what is contained within an image we have image segmentation also known as semantic
segmentation which is like object detection but it applies the object detection to every pixel in the image so
each pixel represents an A type of object other face analysis tools which allow us
to detect faces compare faces detect facial landmarks determine gender and age detect facial features and classify
emotions we have other body analysis tools which allow us to estimate poses recognize gestures count the number of
fingers you're holding up and detect adult or racy content and other document analysis tools which
allow us to extract printed text handwritten text form data and tables from documents and this is an area
that's growing quite rapidly especially in the pre-trained AI model space because we have so many analog forms
that need to be digitized but in addition to the image analysis tools that we've just seen there's also a
variety of image synthesis tools now and these tools include image completion image Generation image style transfer
and more so let's take a look at image completion which is also known as image in painting or content aware fill
so image completion allows us to fill in the missing area of an image with a best guess as to what should likely go there
in the missing contents essentially it answers the question what should go in this missing part of the image for
example we can use image completion to digitally remove unwanted objects we provide the model with an image and then
a mask containing the object we want removed then the model produces a new image with that object digitally removed
from the image or the background filled in as its output
now this is useful for digitally removing objects from artifacts from images filling in the missing area
outside of the photos borders and restoring image quality to old or damaged photos
but Beyond image completion there's a variety of other tools available for image synthesis for example image

image coloration which allows us to convert black and white photos into full color images
super resolution which allows us to zoom and enhance uh the image quality of low

when we combine images uh with audio synced over time we get video and video
allows us to perceive the world as a continuous and Fluid Audio Visual experience
video data are composed of both a visual component and an audio component the visual component is consists of a series
of static images that are all stacked over time and the audio component is synced with the images to produce a
temporally coherent audio visual experience video data can either be mono that is 2D
2D images or stereo which is 3D images and the audio can once again be either one channel audio or the single monorail
audio or stereo two channel audio and by adding these additional audio and video channels it improves the accuracy of our
models and allows them to perform more complex tasks that couldn't be performed with just a single Channel
keep in mind that we can perform all of the existing tasks that we've seen in the audio and the video audio and image
section however the temporally coherent sequence of images and audio combined allows us to perform some new tasks that
we couldn't perform with just images or just audio um and this leads to a variety of AI
tools that we can use for video analysis including motion detection object tracking action recognition and more so

end-to-end AI applications we're essentially training a single giant model or larger machine learning model to perform all of the same tasks all at
once now there are various pros and cons to each of these approaches to creating AI applications modular AI systems are
easier to create maintain and debug however they require domain expertise and lots of code to wire the modules
together whereas these end-to-end AI applications are more efficient more
powerful and less biased however they're much harder to create they require much more data to train and unfortunately
they're not transparent as all it's really difficult to see what's happening in the middle of one of these end-to-end
AI applications so my general advice is to always start with a modular AI application first start by decomposing
the problem into its constituent sub problems then solve each of these smaller sub problems with a specifically
focused machine learning model and then finally you wire these various models together to create that full solution

physical system is essentially a machine that can sense the world around it and then choose actions to achieve a goal of some kind for example a robot vacuum
cleaner that vacuums your floors uh collaborative robots also known as cobots that work alongside humans and
self-driving cars that drive you to and to your destination while avoiding obstacles
so these cyber physical systems combine a variety of sensors to sense the world around them in addition they include a
variety of actuators to physically act upon the world around them essentially the sensors and the actuators are the
inputs and outputs of this cyber physical system function and once again we can conceptualize this
cyber physical system as a function the system receives sensory data as its input and then it produces an action of
some kind as its output however with cyber physical systems this function is a bit more complex than the
previous AI functions that we've seen so we're going to walk through the
iterative function here so you can get a better understanding of what this look like looks like but please keep in mind that this is a vast oversimplification
for the sake of time I'm just kind of previewing so you can see how all of this fits together and how somebody would actually go about building like a
self-driving car so first we have the current state of the environment this is the state of the world that the system
currently exists within now next we sense the world using a series of sensors the sensors convert the state of
the world into Digital Data these data can either be audio images or video like we've previously seen or they
can include data from other types of sensors like Velocity Radar GPS and more
then we apply perceptual machine learning models to the sensor data these models like we've already seen convert
the sensor data into features features are abstract representations of
the physical world we merged the sensor data together in a process called Sensor Fusion and we represent these various
features in what's called feature space you can think of it like the system's mental model of the world that it exists
Within next we use a planning engine to develop a plant of action and the planning
engine is often a combination of explicit programming constrained optimization and a type of machine
learning called reinforcement learning so with reinforcement learning we provide reward signals for actions that
lead the Cyber physical system closer to its goal and Punishment signals which are negative rewards for actions that
lead it further away from its goal and now using these rewards and punishments for Behavioral reinforcement the system
learns to choose actions that maximize the expected likelihood of achieving its goal
actions represent everything that the system can possibly do for example accelerate break turn left or turn right
The Chosen action is the one that maximizes that expected likelihood of achieving the system's goals subject to
a series of constraints which the constraints are typically hard coded and then finally The Chosen action is fed to
the actuators actuators include the motors and other outputs that can physically affect the state of the world
around the system and these actuators then are essentially physically acting upon the world with that appropriately
chosen action however the change state of the world with each action also becomes input for the next iteration of
this iterative function so we typically have to repeat this Loop several times a second choosing new actions with each
